awd_titl_txt: Automation Workforce Development through Aligned Industry Partnerships and Training - Project ADAPT
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a growing demand in manufacturing industries for well-qualified mechatronics technicians with skills in industrial automation processes. In rural communities near Western Technical College in western Wisconsin, there has been a rising difference between the manufacturing processes used in the region's industries and those in urban areas. Advanced processes are slower to be adopted in this rural setting. Educational programs in mechatronics are also hard to find in these rural locations. This situation makes it more difficult to supply the technicians needed to support an advanced manufacturing workforce. The potential innovation of the United States is affected as rural industries and populations trail behind on manufacturing processes and training programs. To help address this issue, Western Technical College will develop an advanced mechatronics program to prepare more technicians with the necessary skills to support industrial automation. This project has the potential to increase the efficiency of rurally-located populations to produce advanced manufacturing technicians. It will also provide a model that could be adopted by other institutions. The project will contribute to the nation's economic competitiveness by addressing a crucial piece of this skills improvement challenge on a regional level. 

This project will develop and implement advanced manufacturing courses for the Automation Program at Western Technical College. The courses are based on a proven apprenticeship model at the Applied Sciences College in Mosbach Germany. These courses will merge traditional classroom and apprenticeship philosophies by engaging industry in workforce exposure as well as content delivery. Students will be immersed in classroom learning and application of their knowledge on the job site multiple times while earning their associate degree. The project will also focus on enhancing career pathways in mechatronics for students. It will leverage partnerships with a consortium of rural secondary schools to support dual-credit mechatronics courses for high-school students and advanced standing upon completion. Collaboration with the University of Wisconsin-Stout will also be used to co-develop courses in a 2+2 mechatronics degree pathway for students who want to advance their degrees. Throughout completion and documentation of project successes and challenges, the project will generate best practices and help serve as a model for recruitment, retention, persistence, and modified apprenticeship delivery methods. Project results will be shared through ongoing outreach and education efforts on regional, statewide, and national levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project ADAPT Outcomes

Project ADAPT was a unique collaboration between Western Technical College, Ashley Furniture Industries, the Trempealeau Valley Co-op (TVC2.0), and the University of Wisconsin Stout, focused on cultivating skilled manufacturers in rural Wisconsin through the development of a K-20 model of education in the area of mechatronics. Specific activities of the project were based around the three goals of (1) increasing industry recognized mechatronic training opportunities, (2) increasing recruitment, retention, graduation, and employment of the skilled mechatronic workforce, and (3) expanding industry commitment to expanding the support of a co-delivery of courses. During the three-year project, significant accomplishments were made towards the fulfillment of the identified goals.

Intellectual Merit for Goal 1-

The Project ADAPT partnership established a new degree offering and curriculum in the areas of Mechatronics and Robotic Engineering, IoT Integration Specialist, and a revised Electromechanical program. A system was then developed where high school educators were able to participate in professional development of the new coursework to deliver the courses for dual credit through a mobile skills laboratory which traveled between the partner locations. Students then can test for Smart Automation Certification Alliance credentials and have a direct pathway into the workforce upon high school graduation or Western and the credits also transfer 100% to the partnering institutions of UW-Stout and UW-Oshkosh.

Specific new course development and implementation was completed in the areas of Rapid Proto-typing, Robotic Maintenance, Robotic Programming, Tag-Based HMI/SCADA Systems, Siemens Control Systems, Safeguarding and Circuits, Intro to Mechatronics, Intro to Industrial Controls, Intro to Industrial Robotics, Into to IIoT, and Mechatronics Internship. In total, 13 secondary and post-secondary educators received professional development in one, or all, of these areas.

Broader Impacts of Goals 1-3-

Project ADAPT created a replicable model for secondary schools, businesses, and industry partners to follow while also demonstrating that such activities can create additional interest and understanding within a career field. Western and the project partners exposed secondary school students to a total of 2,746 mechatronic focused models, with the average student completing 28.9 models. Of the 60 taking courses for dual credit, students went on to earn 10 Smart Automation Certification Alliance (SACA) certificates. Upon completion of the training, 36% of participants signified they had more potential to select mechatronics as a career path and 61% indicated that they were at least somewhat likely to pursue more education after being exposed in the mobile skills laboratory. Unfortunately, data on matriculation numbers into full academic programs is limited because over 69% of participants who took courses in high school had not yet graduated at the time of the project ending.

Western and the project partners succeeded in raising the awareness among grant participants of mechatronics career opportunities and the opportunity to earn dual credit through the mobile skills lab. In one survey 108 of the 139 participants had NOT yet taken a course in the mobile skills lab however 100% of them had heard of it and 68% knew some detail about it. Of those who did partake in the mobile skills lab courses, their knowledge of the concept of Industry 4.0 increased from 32% to 68% (significant and moderate awareness). The same population reported an increase in the awareness of career opportunities available in mechatronics (from 42% to 67%). 

 

Close employer involvement during the creation of the mechatronic pathways and courses was crucial for project success. The investment in a mobile skills lab allowed for instruction of advanced technical content to be delivered in rural areas. Additionally, the coalition of secondary schools allowed for a common class bell schedule, making it feasible for students to attend classes at any location the mobile skills lab was present. Collaboration of rural districts is essential due to limited budgets and student populations. Through the model developed here, students have access to coursework otherwise not possible in smaller communities. Employer satisfaction of the content was also achieved with 100% of participating employer survey respondents agreeing that the curriculum addresses the technical/hard skills needed for the job and it would help graduates to get entry level positions within the company. 83% of respondents also indicated that the curriculum includes information necessary for students to succeed within this industry. Employer respondents were less satisfied that the soft skills needed were included (40% agree and 60% neither agree or disagree) in the curriculum highlighting the need for continued focus on educating students in both technical and soft-interpersonal skills.

The last objective of the project was to increase the number of employers expressing interest in engaging in project activities. Since the inception of Project ADAPT, 2 more local employers have committed to working on the mechatronic efforts and the initial industry partner has agreed to assist in finding ways to have more courses taught by qualified, industry experts.

 


Last Modified: 10/25/2021
Modified by: Josh Gamer
